block.p: White House Reviewing American Aid to Russia The White House has begun a comprehensive review of all American aid programs to Russia that were set up to stop the spread of nuclear, biological and chemical weapons.

Putin Shakes Up Kremlin President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia replaced his defense and interior ministers and dismissed the atomic energy chief. He said the changes created a team that would reconcile Russia's sharply reduced military resources with its ambitions to be a more effective military power and salesman of nuclear energy.

Israel Retaliates for Attacks Helicopters hit bases and training camps of Yasir Arafat's personal security forces after a suicide bombing killed two Israeli teenagers, the third bomb attack this week.
The Bush administration, casting its first veto in the Security Council late Tuesday, scuttled Palestinian hopes for a United Nations observer force in Israeli-occupied territories.

Arab leaders at a two-day meeting in Amman, Jordan, pledged new financial support for the Palestinian Authority, but discussions on lifting United Nations sanctions against Iraq collapsed in bitterness.

U.S. Aid to Belgrade to Resume The Bush administration is prepared to certify that Yugoslavia is cooperating with the war crimes tribunal at The Hague, thus meeting the requirements of an American law and allowing American economic assistance to resume, officials said.

Macedonia Forces Press Rebels Government forces mounted an operation against ethnic Albanian rebels in the north, near the Kosovo border, in a last effort to rout the guerrillas before political talks begin. A spokesman said the government wanted a ''political and economic dialogue'' with ethnic Albanian political parties.
Zapatistas' Plea to Congress Masked leaders of the rebel group were given the floor in Mexico's Congress to defend a proposed constitutional amendment guaranteeing new rights for 10 million Indians.

Senate Finds Consensus On Hard-Money Limits The Senate voted, 84 to 16, to raise the post-Watergate limits on regulated donations to candidates and political parties. Individuals would be able to give up to $2,000 per election to a federal candidate and a cumulative total of $37,500 a year to all federal candidates and political parties.
Bush Budget Plan Advances The House approved, 222 to 205, a broad outline of the president's budget for the next fiscal year.
U.S. Firm on Climate Treaty The Bush administration affirmed that it would not submit the Kyoto Protocol for Senate ratification.
The European Union expressed dismay at the announcement.

Army Division Is Downgraded The Army has given one of its 10 active-duty divisions, the Third Infantry, based at Fort Stewart, Ga., the second-lowest rating for wartime readiness, citing a lack of training and personnel caused by peacekeeping work in the Balkans, Pentagon and Congressional officials said.

Ashcroft Comments Assailed A lawyer for Robert P. Hanssen, an F.B.I. agent accused of spying for Moscow, filed a complaint over Attorney General John Ashcroft's remarks concerning the application of the death penalty in espionage cases.

Rate Rise Called Inadequate California's controller issued an analysis showing that the nearly 50 percent increase in energy prices agreed to on Tuesday would still not cover the wholesale prices the state must pay for electricity.

Bomber Shows No Remorse Timothy J. McVeigh admits he carried out the Oklahoma City bombing in a coming book based on death row interviews with him, and he describes the 19 children killed in the blast as ''collateral damage.''

Victory for Abortion Opponents A federal appeals court in San Francisco threw out a $109 million verdict against abortion opponents, ruling that their branding of abortion doctors as ''baby butchers'' and criminals is protected speech.

Acting Treasurer Quits Over Conflict Issue Isabel Miranda resigned as acting treasurer of New Jersey five days into the job and withdrew from consideration for the permanent post. The state's top ethics officer said Ms. Miranda had not fully disclosed her potential conflict of interest involving a leave from her employer, U.S. Trust Company of New Jersey.

Verniero Says Aides Saw Files Peter G. Verniero, New Jersey's attorney general from 1996 until his appointment to the State Supreme Court in 1999, testified at a State Senate hearing that he assigned subordinates to look into reports about the treatment of minority drivers by the state police. But he said he rarely followed up to learn what they had found.

New Carnegie Hall Executive Robert J. Harth, 44, the son of two concert violinists and the longtime chief executive of the Aspen Music Festival and School in Colorado, was chosen to head Carnegie Hall, which weathered a turbulent period under its outgoing leadership.
Seton Hall Coach Departing Tommy Amaker resigned to become head coach of the University of Michigan's basketball team.
N.F.L. Owners' Meeting Instant replay got a three-year renewal, and some player headgear -- bandannas and stocking caps worn under helmets -- was banned.
Maude Russell Rutherford A singer and dancer in the glory days of black theater in the 1920's, she always said it was really she who introduced the Charleston on Broadway. She was thought to be 104.

Stock Markets Backtrack The Nasdaq, which was up 7.8 percent since last Thursday, plunged 6 percent. The S.& P. 500 fell 2.4 percent, wiping out about half of its recent rally, and the Dow lost 1.6 percent, gouging its 5.9 percent rebound.
Leather Prices Moving Up The recent slaughters and burning of European livestock to combat various diseases have helped drive up the price of steer hides by about 12 percent in the last six weeks.
Insurer in Talks With Bank The big German insurer Allianz was said to be in advanced negotiations to acquire Dresdner Bank in a deal potentially valued at $19 billion.

Inquiry Set on Gas Pricing Federal regulators ordered a hearing to investigate the concerns of California officials that one of the nation's largest energy companies, El Paso, set out to manipulate the price of natural gas flowing to the state.
Editorials: A strong vote against soft money; Arab League belligerence; misjudgments by an acting governor.
